Understate: The claim may understate the number of Texas 4-year-olds enrolled in state-backed pre-kindergarten, as there were approximately 181,000 enrolled in 2008-09, according to the National Institute for Early Education Research.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it does not provide evidence or data to back up the assertion that the proposals opening pre-kindergarten to all Texas 4-year-olds never got heard or voted out of committee.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the lack of progress on the proposals is solely due to them not being heard or voted out of committee, without considering other potential reasons for their failure.
Exist alternative explanation: There may be alternative explanations for the failure of the proposals, such as political opposition or conflicting priorities within the legislative sessions.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that Texas is already ranked number one in the number of 4-year-olds attending public-school pre-K, suggesting that there is already access to pre-K programs for a significant portion of Texas 4-year-olds.
Exaggerate: The claim may exaggerate the lack of progress on the proposals by stating that they were never heard or voted out of committee, without providing evidence of any attempts or discussions regarding the proposals.
